thread.title: Why Iowa and New Hampshire are so important to John Kasich and other presidential candidates
thread.title_full: Why Iowa and New Hampshire are so important to John Kasich and other presidential candidates | cleveland.com

author: Henry J. Gomez, Northeast Ohio Media Group
title: Why Iowa and New Hampshire are so important to John Kasich and other presidential candidates
text:
CLEVELAND, Ohio â€“ John Kasich is spending Friday in New Hampshire, marking his 15 th trip this year to the home of the first presidential primary.
No state is more important to the Ohio governor's White House ambitions.
This week, after Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus openly floated the idea of removing Iowa and New Hampshire from their early spots on the caucus and primary calendar, Kasich was first to declare outrage .
"Voters in these states take their responsibility seriously and are among the most active, knowledgeable voters anywhere in the nation," he said. "By requiring that candidates engage directly with the voters, every candidate is tested and judged fairly. I strongly urge the RNC to preserve New Hampshire and Iowa's earned status as first in the nation."
Kasich recently stepped up his efforts in Iowa. But it's New Hampshire, with its open primary and independent-minded voters, that offers a better fit for his centrist politics.
So how have both states "earned" their status?
Since 1980, a period spanning nine election cycles, only three Republicans have won their party's nomination without winning Iowa's caucus. All three righted themselves by winning New Hampshire's primary. Likewise, only two Republicans have been nominated without winning New Hampshire. But they both won in Iowa.
History tells us that if you lose both, you lose the nomination.
Let's take a look back through the years. Our slideshow begins here .
